conclusion: To determine how shadows A, B, C, and D change, we need to consider principles of shadow formation and how the light source's position affects shadow direction and length.
The first image shows shadows A, B, C, and D cast by objects when the light source is positioned directly above them.
Shadows are formed on the opposite side of the light source relative to the objects.
The light source moves to the back left above the objects, meaning the light now comes from a different angle compared to the initial setup.
When the light source moves to the back left, the shadows will shift directionally to the front right of the objects.
The angle of the light source will cause the shadows to elongate in the direction opposite to the light source's new position.
Shadow A, initially directly below the object, will shift to the front right of the object when the light source moves to the back left.
Shadow B will move to the front right and elongate due to the new angle of the light source.
Shadow C will shift to the front right, following the same principle as the other shadows.
Shadow D will move to the front right and elongate as the light source is now positioned to the back left.
All shadows (A, B, C, and D) will be positioned to the front right of their respective objects, indicating the light source is now coming from the back left.

When the light source moves to the back left above the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will shift to the front right of their respective objects and elongate due to the change in the angle of the light source.
